Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Refugee Incorporation and Social Services in the United States

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Refugees resettled to the U.S. benefit from immediate access to U.S. social services in ways that most immigrants do not. When refugees arrive, they initially receive refugee-specific services from their resettlement agency and then quickly transition to general welfare programs. Benefits such as food stamps (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program or SNAP) and Medicaid fill in the critical gaps not covered by resettlement assistance or eventual employment in entry-level jobs. Institutional factors matter in immigrant incorporation, yet we know little about how refugee-specific and general assistance programs differentiate the experience of arriving refugees. Refugee relationships to social services is further shaped by the city and state in which they are resettled. Decisions at the federal level disperse refugees to places that vary in their social policies and political climate. While the consequences of these decisions are felt at the local level by refugees, service providers, and communities, we know little about how refugee incorporation plays out in the approximately 350 destinations throughout the U.S. that receive refugees. This research examines resettlement in a diverse city with a history of immigration and a city that is not considered a traditional immigrant destination in order to understand the role of social services in refugee lives. Findings will contribute to discussion of how best to support refugees in localities across the U.S. and make the most efficient use of social services.

This project uses participant observation and semi-structured interviews to examine the role of social service receipt in refugee lives as they incorporate into different resettlement contexts. Interviews in both cities focus on resettlement from the points of view of four key respondent subgroups. The project will conduct a total of 135 interviews to capture a multitude of perspectives on resettlement, including with: 1) 60 refugees from several countries of origin; 2) 40 representatives from local institutions (resettlement agencies, social service providers, local government, and schools); 3) 20 community members not formally employed to work with refugees; and 4) 15 interviews with national policymakers. Interviews will show how refugees interact with community institutions, how local communities respond to refugees, and how resettlement evolves beyond the walls of the resettlement agency. Observational and interview data will be analyzed and coded using Atlas.ti. This project will inform sociological theories on social service usage, new immigrant destinations, and refugee resettlement in the U.S.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Contrary to other immigrants, refugees resettled to the U.S. arrive with social rights akin to citizens. They receive refugee-specific services from their local refugee resettlement agency and then quickly transition to general assistance programs that fill in the critical gaps as they seek employment. Institutional factors matter in immigrant incorporation, yet we know little about how refugee-specific and general assistance programs differentiate the incorporation of refugees. Refugees’ relationship to social services is further shaped by the city and state in which they are resettled. Decisions at the federal level disperse refugees to places that vary in their social policies and political climate. While the migration literature has examined immigrants’ interactions with local bureaucracies in various types of destinations, there remains a lacuna in our understanding of how refugees interact with the institutions that grant social benefits.

Based on 12 months of ethnographic fieldwork and 102 interviews with refugees and service providers, this dissertation examines resettlement in San Diego, CA and Boise, ID, which differ in their histories of immigration and approaches social services. My findings contribute to literatures in political sociology, international migration, and refugee studies, leveraging two contrasting cases to better understand how resettlement takes place in distinct destination types. San Diego and Boise have resettled similar refugee groups over the past 15 years. By keeping the Resettlement Agency (RA) and refugee populations consistent across sites, I compare how refugee incorporation plays out differently in San Diego and Boise along two dimensions: 1) histories of immigration and 2) state-based approaches to public assistance.

I find that, regardless of city of resettlement, refugees undergo a process of commodification whereby their wellbeing becomes dependent on employment both through the resettlement program’s emphasis on economic self-sufficiency and federal and state programs’ emphasis on workfare programs. My comparative cases are illustrative of how this process of commodification plays out differently in a state with a generous approach to public assistance (California) and a state where support is highly limited (Idaho). Beyond contributions to academic literature, my findings also have programmatic and policy implications for refugee resettlement in cities like San Diego and Boise. By examining resettlement from the perspective of RA caseworkers and staff as well as refugees, this project sheds light on the conflicting narratives that can breed tensions between service providers and their refugee clients.  

I completed data collection in May 2019, which consisted of twelve months of ethnographic fieldwork (six months per city) and 102 interviews. Fieldwork access was granted by one of the nine national Resettlement Agency, as well as the local affiliate offices in San Diego and Boise. The ethnographic component of this project focused on refugees’ initial resettlement, as well as continued services through the RA and external service providers. I strategically centered my ethnography within the RA, which is subcontracted by the federal government to carry out the work of resettlement, making it an ideal vantage point from which to understand how resettlement policy is implemented at the local level. I shadowed caseworkers in both cities as they went about the daily work of resettling refugees. I witnessed ongoing interactions between refugees and the welfare state, including the Department of Social Services, the Department of Public Health, and educational institutions. Additionally, I spent countless hours with caseworkers as they made home visits and provided continuing support beyond their prescribed duties.

The 102 semi-structured interviews examined resettlement beyond the walls of the RA. Interviews focused on two groups in each city: 1) refugees (60 interviews) and 2) representatives from local institutions (42 interviews). I recruited respondents through local RAs, community events, and snowball sampling. Interviews with refugees represented the multiple countries of origin in each city, including Afghanistan, Burma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Iraq, and Somalia. These refugees had been in the U.S. for more than one year, providing perspectives on longer-term incorporation experiences. Interviews with representatives of local institutions focused on RAs, social service agencies, local government, community organizations, and schools.
